Emily E Laird
My writing consists of critical and personal articles about film and the world of cinema that I call home. I’m a film student and a hobby photographer.
Apr 7

Being Awestruck

I woke up this morning to a surprisingly beautiful sunrise. Bright yellow and burnt orange, with swipes of light pink, and swells of royal purple hues. Looking at it, I couldn’t remember the last time I saw one that beautiful.

Movies can leave us awestruck too, those moments are not all that different from nature. The moments when we actually stop everything and truly appreciate something, we are brought back into awareness that the world is bigger than our own limited range of vision. Emotionally and visually, movies allow us to experience so much of life that we normally would never encounter.

When I was younger, maybe 12 or 13, Lawrence of Arabia (1962) was the first movie to visually leave me in awe. I had never seen such an environment before, seeing all of that open space was amazing to me. It still leaves me in awe today, maybe not in the same way. Today I watch it thinking about composition, blocking, and structure, but occasionally I find myself still in awe of that vast beautiful desert. The film in a more broad sense examines man, ego, nature, and the realization of one’s own capabilities. There are so many subtle things in the film that I admire for the lasting impressions they leave. I will never forget when Lawrence changes into his white and gold robes, looking at himself in the reflection of his dagger, a spot of pure white in the dusty sand. We can almost see his ego and that savior complex growing. The lone white horse on the train, as soon as we see that horse we just know it is destined to become his.

Nearly every shot in The Leopard (1963) could easily be mistaken for a painting at first glance. Your eyes are overwhelmed with detail, movement, and color. Visconti’s images are so lush you can almost feel them. Clearly the battle scenes and the famous ballroom scene (pictured) are the standouts in the film. But make no mistake every shot is worth framing. All of Visconti’s films are visually stunning, but The Leopard seems to be operating on a bit of a different level than any of his other films, coming close only to Senso (1954). This film differs itself I think because it covers a very dynamic family story within its narrative, this gives it a lot of variety, a heavy sense of time, and you can feel the history of this family, this lifestyle they live, in the film. Senso is just as fabulous, just in a different, more concentrated way.

I could write endlessly about films like Cleopatra (1963), The River (1951), Lola Montes (1955), Black Narcissus (1947), everything Wes Anderson, and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (1964) but I want to selfishly talk about one of my favorite technicolor films of all time: The Red Shoes (1948).

It was actually the first Criterion edition film I had ever bought, I knew it was a favorite of Martin Scorsese’s, and at that time that was all I needed to know. This beloved Powell and Pressburger film needs no introduction. Technicolor was made for this film, it shows just how effective and powerful color could be in a narrative film. It adds so much drama, mood, and contrast while still not being overpowering, and it never feels artificial. With time one problem that many technicolor films have faced is the artificial look, age has a lot to do with it but, like any other medium in film-making, technicolor needed to be finessed and used carefully, with purpose, and this was not always the case (I won’t name names). If technicolor looks artificial there needs to be an artistic reason for it (Like in Umbrellas of Cherbourg) , otherwise that tells me that it’s just being used improperly. The Red Shoes avoids a lot of these issues in part because its source material is a fairy tail, so our suspension of disbelief is heightened. It’s intensity is also gradual in the film, the brightest most vibrant sequence is at the end of the film during the final dance number. Powell and Pressburger are also true masters of film-making, so that also has a lot to do with it. The image that seems to have left a strong impression on me has got to be the earlier scene where she is performing Swan Lake. After those amazing spins she stops and we see a close up of her face, bright red lipstick, sharp eyebrows, and the her long black eye lashes. It sets the tone for the rest of film, and we see such intensity on her face. And of course the Ballet of the Red Shoes at the very end is unrivaled. I can picture her dancing through the cascade of colored gel sheets floating through the air.

With films like To the Wonder (2012), Knight of Cups (2016), and Tree of Life (2011) Terrence Malick’s films are pretty much engineered so that every aspect is working to awe you, this has earned him both acclaim and criticism. I personally was moved most by To the Wonder. This might be due to the fact that it was my first Malick film, but I was still taken away with it and, I’ll admit, the imagery alone was enough to consume me emotionally. I understand the argument that Malick is all visuals and lacks substance, but I disagree with it.

Instead I feel like his films should be viewed more as those fleeting moments of beauty in life, those moments that often go by us and we don’t stop to linger on them. Malick lingers, and he shows you these moments, that is what most of his films are composed of. They are narratives, but they are stories of these moments in his characters lives. His films are like patchwork quilts (for the lack of a more elegant analogy), the narrative serves as the stitching, but the substance, the fabric, is pure emotion. Trying to watch his films from a more traditional narrative stand point is the problem, you cannot do this with most of Malick’s work. He is speaking to your emotions, not your mind. His style is not for everyone, but you should go into his films with a more open and altered mindset, you won’t be watching just any film if your watching Malick.

Lost in Translation (2003) is another film I revisit often and each time I am both renewed by it and take away a new understanding from it. This is one of the films I go to for an emotional cleanse.

There hasn’t been a single time I have watched it and not left it without feeling rejuvenated in some way. The visuals are beautiful, but this film awes me more emotionally than visually. We have two seemingly polar opposite characters in Bob and Charlotte, but these two meet and one of the most pure and beautiful friendships emerges onscreen. Both characters are at important (and very different) points in their lives, both are completely out of their respective elements in Tokyo, and both of them are lonely. It’s this duality between Bob and Charlotte that interests me most. Right now I connect with Charlotte most, I understand her, I know how it feels to be young and unsure of what you’re going to and be in life, I know what an unfulfilling relationship feels like. I understand Bob, but the connection is only surface deep. I’m sure the older I get, the more I experience, I will connect with Bob more, but it’s not my time quite yet. That’s the beauty of the film, any work of art that has the power to move you, even just once, has touched a core in us both mentally and emotionally.

The famous dialogue between the two actors at the very end of the film, as some of you might have already researched, has been revealed as being “I have to be leaving, but I won’t let that come between us, OK?” Now, I don’t know this for sure, but research seems to reveal that this is the consensus for the famous whisper. Just like the film, I feel like analyzing it in this moment would take away its purpose, it is going to change meaning every time you watch the film (at least it will for me). That is the magic of these films, they are dynamic things that change sometimes just as much as we do. We change, so the films change along with us, at least the ones that are worth anything do. They become more beautiful, like that sunrise. But with each interpretation or viewing the beauty is fleeting and changes, because the next time you wake up that sunrise will not look the same, just like when I watch Lost in Translation again it will carry a whole new meaning than it did before.
